sense.name: hot vapor that results from combustion
sense.examples: Several people were treated for inhalation of smoke, after the nightclub fire. A black plume of smoke could be seen rising from the building. Where there's smoke, there's fire. When John accelerated, a puff of smoke came out the tailpipe of his car.

sense.name: fog produced from water vapor and glycol-based fluid
sense.commentary: SMOKE[+substance][+chemical][+fog][+of_particles][+fine] Note: not a hot vapor from burning (Sense 1)
sense.examples: Theatrical smoke drifted across the stage to produce the effect of fog. Sally wants a smoke machine at her wedding to make her grand appearance.

sense.name: anything illusory, not concrete or real
sense.examples: His dreams of starting a business turned into smoke. The whole argument is nothing but smoke and mirrors.

sense.name: a rolled up form containing tobacco
sense.examples: John bummed a smoke off Sally. The carpenter left his smokes on the back porch. She offered him one of her smokes.

sense.name: the act of smoking
sense.examples: The two employees stood outside in the rain having a smoke. John was dying for a smoke. Her son hasn't had a smoke in six months.

sense.name: data which provides evidence for a hidden or covert activity
sense.commentary: SMOKE[+relation][+role][+data][+evidence][+of_activity][+covert] Note: a metaphoric, idiomatic usage of Sense 1
sense.examples: Where there is smoke, there's fire.

sense.name: street name for marijuana
sense.examples: The drug dealer sells smoke and pills to high school students.

sense.name: a very fast-pitched baseball
sense.examples: The pitcher threw nothing but smokes the first inning. The smoke went over the plate just above the batter's knees.
